awd_titl_txt: 34th Summer Conference on Topology and Its Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The 34th Summer Conference on Topology and its Applications (SUMTOPO 2019) will take place in Johannesburg, South Africa, July 1 - 4, 2019  with sessions from diverse areas of topology. New this year is the session on topology in data science, complimenting the NSF "big idea" of Harnessing Data for 21st Century Science and Engineering. At SUMTOPO 2019, we will bring together established researchers, early career faculty, and students from all over the world to make progress on the unsolved foundational problems in mathematics while also applying our topological expertise to other areas of mathematics and other fields of study. In particular, mathematicians are using topological methods to understand the structure of data. Results presented at the conference can be of use to disciplines in which big data forms an important part. A main goal of the conference series is to promote participation of young researchers by making room for many contributed talks and also by highlighting young researchers as semi-plenary speakers. Organizers continue to recruit women and other under-resented groups to the conference. 

This year's SUMTOPO will include plenary speakers and daily sessions in the areas of set-theoretic topology, continuum theory and dynamics, asymmetric structures and order, topological algebra and analysis, and topology in data science. This grant will support the travel of US-based participants who are students, early in their career, have no other travel support, or are members of an under-represented population. The featured lectures will highlight cutting edge research in each of the represented areas while the sessions provide a vibrant and welcoming space for researchers, established and new, to share ideas and form connections. The conference webpage is: https://www.sumtopo2019.co.za/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 34th Summer Conference on Topology and its Applications was held July 1 to 4, 2019 in Johannesburg, South Africa. There were 5 special sessions and 16 invited speakers, including young researchers and members of underrepresented groups. There were also 59 contributed talks within the sessions. Participants were recruited by the organizers advertising locally, the steering committee contacting past participants, and by contacting individual data science programs targeting students and early career faculty. We also advertised in mathematical outlets in the US.

A total of 98 participants attended the conference representing 25 countries and 14 US states, with around 30% coming from the US and 30% coming from South Africa. Representatives came from African countries: DRC, Ghana, Kenya, South Africa, and Tunisia. Other countries represented were Canada, the Cech Republic, China, England, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, India, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Mexico, the Netherlands, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Slovenia, Spain, Switzerland, and Ukraine.

 The impact of this award was strong with our US supported participants. During the recruiting process and in a follow up survey, most indicated that they simply would not have been able to attend without the support. The students in particular expressed excitement and gratitude about attending such a vibrant and international conference. 

Below we give highlights of the mathematical program.

Topological Algebra and Analysis

Taras Banakh (Ivan Franko Lviv National University, Ukraine) discussed notions of completeness of topologized posets, and surveyed some recent results on closedness properties of complete topologized semi-lattices. Mahmoud Filali (University of Oulu, Finland) presented on algebra in the Stone-Cech compactification versus algebra in Banach algebras with an Arens product.

Francesco Russo (University of Cape Town, South Africa) described three theorems of structure for locally compact near abelian groups.

Asymmetric Structures and Order

Aysymmetric structures has been an important part of the summer conference since the beginning and has a particularly strong group in Africa. Szymon Dolecki (Burgundy University, France) talked about pseudopaving number of dual spaces comparing its strength to the topological framework. Seithuti Philemon Moshokoa (Tshwane University of Technology, South Africa) presented properties of partial symmetric spaces with some applications. Michel Schellekens (University College Cork, Ireland) spoke about Thermodynamic algorithms: modularity and entropy conservation.

Dynamics and Continuum Theory

A recent PhD graduate, Daron Anderson (NUI Galway, Ireland), presented  a Bellamy continuum with a strong non-cut point and a Bellamy continuum which is metrizable and is small in the sense of being separable. Judy Kennedy (Lamar University, USA) presented her work on building a homeomorphism on a pseudoarc with positive non-infinite entropy from a construction of Mary Rees that modified a minimal homeomorphism on a torus to produce one with positive entropy. Another recent PhD graduate, Petra Staynova (University of Leicester) talked about the relationship between classical dynamical properties and the algebraic structure of the Ellis semigroup. She explored some links between the Ellis semigroup, its minimal ideals, and the dynamics of the underlying system.

Set-Theoretic Topology

The early career researcher and Mary Ellen Rudin award winner, Osvaldo Guzman Gonzalez (University of Toronto), spoke about the Katetov order on MAD families. Another early career researcher, Rodrigo Hernandez (Universidad Autónoma Metropolitana, Mexico), spoke on Countable dense homogeneity of functions spaces. Continuing the theme of homogeneity in this session this year, Jan van Mill (University of Amsterdam, Netherlands) presented on Splitting Tychonoff cubes into homeomorphic and homogeneous parts. Dilip Raghavan (National University of Singapore, Singapore) talked about order dimension of locally countable partial orders, in particular the axioms of ZFC do not decide the order dimension of the Turing degrees.

 Topology in Data Science

Our newest session, Data Science, drew experts and students. Frederic Chazal (Inria Saclay) presented on a graph classification using a general neural network architecture to process persistence diagrams and their representations. Vladimir Itskov (Pennsylvania State University, USA) presented on Directed complexes and convex sensing. Yusu Wang (Ohio State University, USA) spoke about Topological and geometric methods for graph analysis
